channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: Sony said it has stopped selling its PlayStation console and software in Russia, and has shut down the PlayStation Store in the country https://t.co/8ipjiw8HUf

“They want to kill as many civilians as possible,” said the deputy mayor of Mariupol, where more than 1,200 civilians have died after over a week of Russian shelling. “They will not allow for evacuation. They deliberately target lines for water and food.” https://t.co/TNDx1JOck2

The U.S. and its allies are walking a fine line in Ukraine, seeking to help the Ukrainians thwart the Russian invasion while avoiding crossing Russian red lines and getting pulled into a direct conflict with a nuclear-armed adversary https://t.co/Ser2psV6Ku

Watch: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has propelled President Volodymyr Zelensky onto the world stage. We look at how the former television star's use of social media brought his wartime messages to a global audience. https://t.co/Blxsyj2TVE

After Russia denied that it had sustained casualties during the early days of the invasion, Ukraine “decided to show pictures and names of the dead soldiers” on the internet, a Ukrainian official said https://t.co/8EovaYGdwD

From @WSJopinion: Biden bemoans today’s skyrocketing gas prices, yet he remains hostage to the green-energy donors whose policies guarantee higher prices. He is enabling Putin’s energy leverage even as he claims the opposite. https://t.co/4SSdXsQiAV

The European Organization for Nuclear Research has paused new scientific collaborations with Russia, joining other scientific institutions in efforts to isolate Russia after its invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/9tMUTSavXS

United Airlines will allow workers who haven’t been vaccinated against Covid-19 for religious or medical reasons to return at the end of this month, according to people familiar with the decision https://t.co/iwVB1ulknm

White House press secretary Jen Psaki lashed out at Russian claims that the U.S. was developing chemical weapons in Ukraine, warning it could be a pretext for Moscow to use such weapons itself https://t.co/rWqmgKGOWH
“Trans-Atlantic strength is back." NATO finds new purpose in opposing Russia. https://t.co/i20yBuyi5J

3M said Wednesday that it is suspending all of its business operations in Russia. The St. Paul, Minn. manufacturer sells its products in the country and operates at least one factory there. https://t.co/sO8LG0JNKB

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said she spoke to Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky for more than 45 minutes on Wednesday, telling reporters, "He wants the planes, the planes, the planes" https://t.co/8zu8cCl6Rd

The United Arab Emirates said it would push the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to pump more oil as crude prices rocket to near record-highs during Russia’s war on Ukraine https://t.co/tmFYZALqyu
Amazon’s board approved a 20-for-1 stock split and authorized the tech giant to make a stock buyback of up to $10 billion https://t.co/5OPnMe4ZB3
The U.S. formally rejected a proposal by Poland to give Soviet-era fighter jets to Ukraine, calling the suggested transfer "high risk" https://t.co/JQBa0Q1pxq

NATO’s unity in response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine surprised even alliance members. Then came Poland's offer to make its Soviet-built MiG-29 combat jets available—though not to Ukraine but the U.S. https://t.co/8TzeLqGfsK

From @WSJopinion: Jews and Ukrainians may be the two peoples readiest to live and die for their freedom—and how their fused spirit lives in Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, writes Ruth R. Wisse https://t.co/iVerRCEKuV
South Koreans elected Yoon Suk-yeol as president, installing a conservative who promises a tougher stance on North Korea and closer ties with the U.S. on regional affairs https://t.co/1xjmVdNGk0
London became Londongrad as Russian oligarchs stormed the high-end property market. Now they are under pressure and so is the real estate market. https://t.co/waTCw9IBRD

Russian President Vladimir Putin in the first days of the Russian invasion of Ukraine ordered his country’s nuclear-deterrence forces to be put on alert, a reminder of the threat posed by the war. Here's what to know about the country's arsenal. https://t.co/m4KrONG8TD
NATO was mired in member disputes just a few years ago. Russia's invasion of Ukraine has given it renewed focus. https://t.co/Jo2KII2rVQ
It isn’t just Ukrainians who are fleeing. Russians are leaving their homeland too. “We are forbidden from even calling it a war.” https://t.co/Yh9gZcinbY

Lada cars have been a symbol of Russia’s self-reliance since the depths of the Cold War. On Wednesday, Lada’s factory floors ground to a halt as Western sanctions deprived its parent company of the parts and supplies it needs to make cars. https://t.co/RWiJ2uX0dF

Skechers said that it had temporarily stopped shipments to Russia last week and that it donated $250,000 in humanitarian aid to Ukraine. It will match employees' donations for up to an additional $250,000. https://t.co/FnonFnS6Jv
The U.K. has tightened its airspace restrictions with the aim of closing loopholes that could be used by wealthy Russian citizens to enter the country https://t.co/buFTTIUjuk

Coca-Cola and McDonald’s are among some of America’s best-known brands that have announced plans to pull back from Russia in response to the country’s invasion of Ukraine #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/UXvzQOStUF https://t.co/MYYJzlRg53
Breaking: A Russian airstrike hit a maternity hospital in the besieged city of Mariupol, burying adults and children under rubble, Ukrainian authorities said https://t.co/y6NzjlkKIE
The wreck of Ernest Shackleton's ship Endurance, which disappeared under Antarctic sea ice in 1915, has been discovered in a "brilliant state of preservation" https://t.co/8o5GIUufoC

The world's second-largest brewer Heineken NV said it would stop the production, advertising and sale of the Heineken brand in Russia as a response to the escalation of the war in Ukraine https://t.co/qQL2kxWfAS

The Ukrainian government says the Chernobyl nuclear power facility now controlled by Russia has lost power, threatening the cooling of radioactive material stored there and risking radioactive leakage https://t.co/nITGmtuhdK
The wreck of Ernest Shackleton's ship Endurance, which disappeared under Antarctic sea ice in 1915, has been discovered in a 'brilliant state of preservation' https://t.co/UkbJwV0VKZ
Poland said it would make its MiG-29 combat jets available to the U.S. after days of talks about how to get planes to Ukraine https://t.co/LrjvcdNxAV
The price for U.S. gasoline hit a record high, tracking a surge in global energy markets and showing how the war in Ukraine is having economic consequences https://t.co/7bJMbu7V54
Venezuela released two Americans who had been detained. The olive branch comes as the U.S. considers lifting sanctions on the country’s oil industry. https://t.co/tPgpWSoXX8

Efforts to implement a cease-fire failed for the fourth day in a row in the southeastern Ukrainian city of Mariupol, where residents have gone without power, cellphone coverage or water supplies for more than a week https://t.co/HEdSjukiZy
Opponents of Myanmar’s junta are pushing for a ban on the sale of jet fuel as the military continues its campaign of airstrikes to counter the armed resistance https://t.co/p5FsmFOfJT

From @WSJopinion: Putin’s assault on Ukraine has caused Germany to revolutionize its defense policy in less than a week. Will the Biden Administration have a similar awakening about defending Americans with dictators on the march? https://t.co/UEVVZwQ0Ef
Removing sensitive equipment allowed the Pentagon to get antiaircraft missiles delivered to Kyiv, but the delay points to larger lessons in sending arms to Ukraine https://t.co/zHtx3NiHQ7

A law-enforcement arm of the Department of Homeland Security participated in a secret bulk surveillance program that collected millions of records about certain money transfers of some Americans without a warrant https://t.co/xPTzNdW0WR
There’s a new iPhone SE, iPad Air and Mac Studio in town. Columnist @nicnguyen explains what’s noteworthy in Apple’s just-announced product line. https://t.co/wdJzQYeDdo
Amos Hochstein, the State Department's energy envoy, says Russia’s attack on Ukraine shows the West should accelerate its push for cleaner energy https://t.co/fDwvzmjXQf
Bumble said Tuesday that it will discontinue its operations in Russia and remove all of its dating apps from the App Store and the Google Play Store in Russia and Belarus https://t.co/hMviFvT91r
He promised Putin a quick victory. Now he could become the scapegoat for Russia's flawed strategy in Ukraine. https://t.co/ME3lSkzRmW
Leaders of Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates declined requests to speak to President Biden during the Ukraine crisis, officials say. They both took calls from Putin. https://t.co/qU2aYCCEQd

Biden administration officials privately told senior Democrats repeatedly that they planned to move forward with a ban on Russian oil imports. When they didn’t deliver, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi decided to move forward on her own, people familiar said. https://t.co/3Ryf9A0cIo
Fitch Ratings cut its credit ratings on Russia further into junk territory and warned that Moscow was likely to default on its debts shortly https://t.co/Gf6j3uo5Du
"I'll be fine," a sailor on a ship stranded off Ukraine reassured his family in Bangladesh. Then the missile came down. https://t.co/CHp039TLa1
Poland said it would make its MiG-29 combat jets available to the U.S. after days of talks about how to get planes to Ukraine https://t.co/ilb5TCaQpC
Proud Boys leader Enrique Tarrio was arrested and indicted on conspiracy and other charges related to the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol https://t.co/YjO0BlEa0q

Venezuela has released a former American oil executive from prison, just days after President Nicolas Maduro met with senior U.S. officials who are considering lifting oil sanctions on Caracas https://t.co/Bi0qm4sLQA
